Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 45058-001 
Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (PATA) 
December 2011 
 
 
 
People’s Republic of China: Promoting Partnerships 
for South–South Cooperation  
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During the December 2010 country programming mission, consultations between the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
highlighted the need to provide support for promoting knowledge sharing and cooperation to 
enhance the development impact of ADB operations in the country. The government requested 
ADB  to  provide  a  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  promote  partnerships  for  South–South 
cooperation.1 The TA is included in the PRC’s country operations business plan, 2011–2013 as 
a firm TA.2  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The unprecedented economic expansion of the PRC over the past decade has placed 
the country in a position to play a critical role in development in the Asia and Pacific region. The 
PRC  recognizes  the  increasing  global  and  regional  expectations  for  it  to  share  in  the 
development of the region. The breadth and depth of the PRC’s development experience and 
knowledge  is  valuable  for  other  developing  countries.  The  PRC  can  also  learn  from  the 
developmental lessons of other countries and build on their successes.  
 
3.  Since 2006, ADB’s East Asia Department has made efforts to integrate knowledge 
management into its operations in the PRC. The department has placed increased emphasis on 
generating knowledge from lending and technical assistance operations, and providing policy-
related knowledge support. It has also strengthened knowledge cooperation with the PRC on a 
number of dimensions, taking full advantage of the PRC’s development experience. Knowledge 
and innovation is a core theme in ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC4. The PRC, in 
partnership  with  ADB,  has  found  a  long-term  solution  to  make  the  knowledge  exchange 
sustainable. A formalized knowledge sharing platform (KSP) would serve as a channel for 
exchanging  good  development  practices,  facilitating  learning  between  developing  member 
countries (DMCs) and the PRC, and ultimately building greater South–South cooperation. 
 
4.  To promote South–South cooperation, the PRC Ministry of Finance (MOF) and ADB 
established a KSP in 2009. This jointly managed KSP is a vehicle to (i) share solutions for key 
emerging development issues and challenges faced by developing countries in the Asia and 
Pacific region, (ii) contribute to sound development management and policy making, and (iii) 
promote regionally inclusive development. It supports ADB’s long-term strategic framework, 
Strategy 2020,5 to drive knowledge solutions as a tool to help countries attain their development 
objectives. It also aligns the knowledge sharing objectives of the PRC and ADB by creating 
learning opportunities that build on their key strengths. ADB plays the role of facilitator to 
promote evidence-based learning between the PRC and other ADB DMCs and contributes to 
the conceptualization, design, and financing of KSP activities. 
 
 
                                                 
1  South-South cooperation is economic cooperation among developing countries aimed at closer policy coordination 
and collaboration in support of regional and global public goods, accelerating economic growth and reducing 
economic disparities. 
2  ADB. 2011. Country Operations Business Plan: People’s Republic of China, 2011–2013. Manila. 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 7  December 2011. 
4   ADB. 2008. Country Partnership Strategy: People’s Republic of China, 2008–2010. Manila. 
5  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila.

2    
5.  The KSP has evolved into a multi-year umbrella for sector-driven knowledge sharing 
initiatives, including regional ones. It facilitates dialogue and knowledge exchange between the 
PRC and other countries in the region. Activities under the KSP include (i) annual thematic 
workshops in the PRC, attended by officials from the PRC and DMCs; (ii) development-related 
case studies and reports shared in these workshops and published on the websites of ADB and 
its partners; (iii) presentations by resource persons from the PRC, DMCs, and ADB on thematic 
topics and case studies from their countries; and (iv) site visits that showcase development 
projects in the PRC. Since 2009, three KSP events have been organized: 
(i)  The  High-Level  Regional  Knowledge-Sharing  Workshop  on  Sustainable 
Urbanization was held in Shanghai, 2–6 November 2009. It was attended by 50 
senior officials from 11 DMCs and discussions focused on (a) sound urbanization 
strategies, (b) good practices and common challenges in urban planning, (c) 
urban renewal and expansion, and (d) urban finance. 
(ii)  The  High-Level  Regional  Knowledge-Sharing  Workshop  on  Transport 
Infrastructure: An Instrument for Economic and Social Development was held in 
Beijing, 8–11 November 2010. It was attended by 70 officials from 15 DMCs and 
discussions  focused  on  (a)  the  role  of  transport  infrastructure  in  promoting 
economic and social development, (b) strategies for road network development 
and planning of road infrastructure, (c) financing of transport infrastructure, (d) 
institutional  capacity  building  to  support  high  performance  in  transport 
infrastructure development and operation, and  (e) addressing adverse impacts 
of transport infrastructure and its contribution to poverty reduction.  
(iii)  The High-Level Regional Knowledge-Sharing Workshop on Agriculture and Rural 
Development was held in Beijing, 7–10 November 2011. It was attended by 70 
officials from 15 DMCs and discussions focused on (a) best practices in farm 
productivity to boost farmers' incomes, (b) agriculture research, (c) green rural 
infrastructure, and (d) rural financial development.   
 
6.  The KSP was showcased as a model South–South learning initiative at the High-Level 
Forum on Aid Effectiveness held on 29 November–1 December 2011 in Busan, Republic of 
Korea. 
 
7.  ADB  has  been  actively  exploring  knowledge  partnerships  with  PRC’s  centers  of 
excellence to expand mutual learning experiences between the PRC and other DMCs in urban 
development, transport sector, water security, and agriculture and rural development. In March 
2010, the PRC urban knowledge hub was established with Tongji University in Shanghai. It is a 
pioneering initiative made possible through the partnership between ADB and Tongji University 
for sharing good practice approaches in urban planning. In 2011, ADB established a knowledge 
partnership jointly with the Tsinghua University, Peking University, and the Asia-Pacific Center 
for Water Security covering the water sector. Preparations for the establishment of the PRC 
transport knowledge hub are under way; it aims to realign transport work in the region to be 
consistent with emerging transport challenges by developing sustainable road or rail networks. 
The PRC agriculture knowledge hub is also being conceptualized. 
 
8.  The  KSP  has  been  a  successful  country-led  platform  for  sharing  experiences  in 
addressing challenges in the urban, transport, and agriculture sectors. The KSP addresses 
several aspects of the Accra Agenda for Action, which serves as the frame of reference for the 
task team for South–South cooperation, including (i) ownership and mutual accountability, (ii) 
addressing  development  challenges,  (iii)  champions  and  incentives,  and  (iv)  triangular 
cooperation.

3
9.  The  KSP  is  an  equitable  and  participatory  approach  that  enhances  ownership  and 
effectiveness of development knowledge sharing. It raises awareness on the emerging needs 
and challenges in the region through a more systematic and structured channel for South–South 
cooperation. Through the KSP, the PRC takes on a leadership role in equal partnership with 
ADB in sharing its development experience with DMCs in the region. 
 
10.  Initial KSP activities have produced good results. Participants successfully shared best 
practices  and  emerging  issues  and  challenges  in  urban  development  and  transport  as 
instruments  of  socioeconomic  development.  Based  on  the  post-workshop  evaluations 
conducted,  participants  valued  the  knowledge-sharing  workshops  as  effective  networking 
vehicles for policy makers that pave the way for future South–South cooperation initiatives. The 
knowledge-sharing workshop on urbanization led to collaboration between ADB and the College 
of Architecture and Urban Planning of Tongji University to establish the urban knowledge hub to 
continue  to  share  urban  best  practices  within  the  PRC  and  with  other  DMCs.  Participant 
feedback included suggestions to hold KSP activities in other DMCs. 
 
11.  The MOF and ADB are now working to position the KSP as a credible and influential 
source of development knowledge in the region. The KSP has the potential to facilitate regional 
cooperation and policy dialogue for regional cooperation around specific sector topics. With 
greater resources and effort, it can achieve that potential by serving as a platform to assist 
exchanges between countries. The KSP is envisaged to become an umbrella for other sector 
activities, particularly regional ones, in order to address similar and shared challenges between 
countries  in  the  Asia  and  Pacific  region.  The  KSP  model  may  be  enriched  by  piloting 
subsequent  workshops  in  other  DMCs  and  rotating  the  host  country  to  learn  from  the 
development achievements and experience of other developing countries. 
 
12.  Given the KSP’s unique role as a knowledge broker in the region, the PRC and ADB are 
well placed to use it to support South–South cooperation so that this knowledge may translate 
to relevant projects with meaningful impacts on people’s lives. As its facilitator, ADB is in the 
best position to evolve the KSP-led dialogue into high-impact policy recommendations and 
outcomes for all participants. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
13.  The impact of the TA will be enhanced knowledge cooperation between the PRC and 
other  DMCs.  The  outcome  of  the  TA  will  be  increased  awareness  of  best  practices  and 
emerging issues and challenges in the region, enabling improved sector policy making and 
capacity building among the PRC and DMCs in the region. Success in achieving the outcome 
will be measured by (i) the increased participation of DMCs in knowledge sharing workshops 
with the PRC and (ii) the improved satisfaction of participants in knowledge sharing workshops. 
The main outputs of the TA are (i) KSP workshops on development themes, (ii) papers prepared 
for the workshops, and (iii) publications on results of the workshops. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
14.  Using  the  KSP,  the  TA  will  carry  out  knowledge-sharing  activities  covering  key 
development constraints and challenges facing the PRC and other DMCs in key sectors and 
themes, as well as opportunities for inclusive, balanced, and sustainable development. Specific 
development issues that are likely to be covered by KSP workshops, publications, and policy

4    
papers include (i) constraints facing the transition of middle-income economies to higher-income 
economies; (ii) international lessons on human capital development and capacity building; (iii) 
success stories on the provision of basic social services; (iv) urbanization; (v) economics of 
climate  change  and  low-carbon  growth  strategies;  (vi)  fiscal  management,  and  the  use  of 
natural  resources;  and  (vii)  environmental  management  practices.  The  TA  will  promote 
horizontal  learning  and  knowledge  exchange,  identify  development  needs,  and  encourage 
enhanced knowledge partnerships. 
 
15.  Key activities to promote South–South cooperation through the KSP platform include (i) 
holding international workshops, conferences, field visits, and study tours to facilitate knowledge 
exchange; (ii) sharing the outputs of the workshops, field visits, and study tours with participants 
and other stakeholders by disseminating reports; and (iii) developing and publishing policy 
documents and posting these on a KSP website. The KSP will become an umbrella for sector 
activities—particularly those of regional nature such as the ADB–PRC urban knowledge hub.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–other sources). The government will 
provide an in-kind contribution through the provision of counterpart staff, office space and 
utilities, transport, and other support activities, including access to data. The cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.   The MOF, as the executing agency, will be responsible for supervising and monitoring 
TA activities. A steering committee—comprising representatives of departments of the MOF and 
ADB—will be set up to oversee implementation, and provide guidance and direction to the 
consultants. The composition of the steering committee will be finalized at TA inception. In 
addition, the MOF will appoint a project coordinator who will supervise and coordinate day-to-
day TA activities, including monitoring progress, resolving problems, arranging meetings, and 
liaising with concerned government agencies. To facilitate the work of the consultants and 
ensure that the MOF benefits from their experience, the MOF will provide adequate counterpart 
staff with relevant work experience during TA implementation. The steering committee will 
provide guidance on organizing programs, workshops, and seminars; selecting participants; and 
identifying  topics  for  workshops,  and  other  TA  activities.  A  workshop  coordinator  may  be 
recruited to support the organization of the workshop.  
 
18.  The TA will be implemented from 31 January 2012 to 31 December 2015. It will 
require  about  8  person-months  of  international  and  about  12  person-months  of  national 
consulting services to carry out the terms of reference (Appendix 3). The international and 
national consultants will have expertise in (i) training and capacity building, (ii) institutional 
development,  (iii)  economic  policy  making,  (iv)  social  development,  (v)  environmental 
management  issues,  and  (vi)  regional  cooperation.  Workshop  coordinators  may  be 
appointed after discussions with the steering committee. The steering committee will discuss 
and finalize the required expertise and detailed terms of reference for specific assignments, 
including  duration  and  expected  results.  Additional  international  and  national  resource 
persons and short-term task-specific experts will be recruited to carry out well-defined tasks 
(e.g., preparing case study papers, creating workshop presentations, presenting papers in 
workshops, and reviewing draft reports).

5
19.  All  consultants  and  resource  persons  will  be  recruited  in  accordance  with  ADB's 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The consultants 
will be recruited on an individual basis since varied expertise will be required for the short-term 
engagement, the main requirements of the assignments are for individual qualifications and 
experience, and the assignments are more on an individual basis. A firm could have difficulty 
providing multidisciplinary expertise over the 3-year implementation period as required by the 
TA. The workshop coordinators will be responsible for team coordination and leadership work. 
Resource  persons  will  be  subject  to  the  limitations  with  regard  to  the  recruitment  and 
compensation of resource persons under ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). Given the nature of the TA and to facilitate preparation and 
implementation of the training and workshops, ADB may establish an advance payment facility 
as needed and/or utilize direct payment to workshop sponsors and workshop venues. Proceeds 
of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  the  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
20.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Promoting Partnerships for South–South 
Cooperation, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8     Appendix 3    
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require 20 person-months of international and national 
consulting services. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will select and engage consultants and 
resource  persons  on  an  individual  basis  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Additional international and national resource 
persons and task-specific experts will be engaged to carry out well-defined tasks (e.g., preparing 
case  study  papers,  creating  workshop  presentations,  presenting  papers  in  workshops,  and 
reviewing draft reports). 
 
2.  Workshop coordinator (international, 2 person-months). The expert will have at least a 
master of arts degree, preferably in economics or management, and 5 years’ work experience in 
project implementation and project coordination with donors and government agencies, including 
organizing and conducting conferences and workshops. The tasks include the following: 
 
(i)  coordinate, design, plan, and conduct national, regional, and local workshops and 
meetings; 
(ii)  examine the most appropriate methods of seeking feedback and consensus of 
participants;  
(iii)  document inputs and provide participants and decision makers with feedback on 
workshop outcomes; and 
(iv)  carry out other tasks as identified by the TA project officer. 
 
3.  Sectoral and thematic experts and resource persons (international, 4 person-months; 
national, 6 person months). These experts will have at least a master of arts degree in economics 
or  their  field  of  specialization  such  as  (i)  training  and  capacity  building,  (ii)  institutional 
development,  (iii)  economic  policy  making,  (iv)  social  development,  (v)  environmental 
management, (vi) regional cooperation, and (vii) other areas identified as strategic thrusts in 
ADB’s country partnership strategy for the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and Strategy 
2020. These experts will have 10 years minimum work experience on sectoral policy issues and 
overall developmental concerns. These experts will be hired on a need basis and will have the 
following tasks:  
 
(i)  review the constraints and issues in the development of Asian economies and 
assess sectoral constraints and challenges to development; 
(ii)  prepare presentations for international workshops; 
(iii)  prepare draft reports on sectoral policy issues based on discussions during the 
 international workshops; 
(iv)  organize peer reviews of papers as needed; and 
(v)  undertake  other  tasks  related  to  the  knowledge  sharing  platform  design  and 
implementation. 
 
4.  Other experts who may receive honoraria or payments (international, 2 person-
months; national, 6 person-months). Additional resource persons and task-specific experts will 
be engaged to carry out well-defined tasks, including the preparing case study papers, workshop 
presentations, presenting papers in workshops, and reviewing draft reports and workshop 
materials.  The  international  and  national  resource  persons  and  experts  will  have  extensive 
experience in their respective fields of specialization and will have expertise in (i) training and 
capacity  building,  (ii)  institutional  development,  (iii)  economic  policy  making,  (iv)  social 
development, (v) environment, (vi) regional cooperation, and (vii) other areas identified as 
strategic thrusts in ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC and Strategy 2020.
